'''Lady Bianca''' (born August 8, 1953) is an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] singer, songwriter and arranger.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=Jason Ankeny |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/lady-bianca-mn0000120932/biography |title=Lady Bianca | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1953-08-08 |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref> She has worked as a [[session musician|session singer]], depicted [[Billie Holiday]] on [[Stage (theatre)|stage]], and since 1995  released six solo [[album]]s, three of which were nominated for a [[Grammy Award]].

She is currently based in [[Oakland, California]].

==Life and career==
She was born '''Bianca Thornton''',<ref name="Room">{{cite book
| first= Adrian
| last= Room
| year= 2010
| title= Dictionary of Pseudonyms: 13,000 Assumed Names and Their Origins
| edition= 5th
| publisher= [[McFarland & Company|McFarland & Company, Inc.]] 
| location= [[Jefferson, North Carolina]]
| isbn= 978-0-7864-4373-4
| page= 271}}</ref> in [[Kansas City, Missouri]], [[United States]].<ref name="AMG"/> She was the eldest child, with two sisters and one brother.<ref name="Dennis"/>

Her first exposure to music was through [[gospel music|gospel]], and she studied at the [[San Francisco Conservatory of Music]].<ref name="AMG"/> Her first professional [[concert|gig]] was with Quinn Harris and the Masterminds, when she was aged 17.  Harris dubbed her 'Lady Bianca', and the combination contributed two tracks to a [[compilation album]] released by Reynolds Records in 1970.<ref name="Dennis"/>

In 1972, she played the role of [[Billie Holiday]] in the San Franciscan stage production of [[Jon Hendricks]]' ''Evolution of the Blues''.<ref name="AMG"/> In the mid 1970s, she worked in various [[nightclub|clubs]] in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], where she met the bass guitarist [[Henry Oden]]. They were subsequently married for 15 years.  She then joined [[Sly and the Family Stone]] as [[backing vocalist]] and keyboard player, and appeared on their 1976 album, ''[[Heard Ya Missed Me, Well I'm Back]]''.  Late the same year she briefly toured with [[Frank Zappa]], and a recording of her singing [[Wind Up Workin' in a Gas Station]]" appeared on the albums ''[[Zoot Allures]]'' and ''[[Philly '76]]'', and was re-released in 1992 on ''[[You Can't Do That on Stage Anymore, Vol. 6]]''.  When not touring, she performed locally in the [[recording studio]], backing musicians such as [[Lee Oskar]], [[Merle Haggard]] and [[Taj Mahal (musician)|Taj Mahal]]. In 1977, she co-founded the short-lived ensemble Vitamin E, and they released the commercially doomed ''Sharing'' album on [[Buddah Records]]. Lady Bianca then joined another group, Zingara, which was set up by [[Lamont Dozier]] in 1980.  The trio included [[James Ingram]], Wali Ali and Lady Bianca, but again it did not have any lasting appeal.<ref name="Dennis"/>    

Between 1981 and 1986, Lady Bianca toured and recorded [[backing vocalist|backing vocals]] for [[Van Morrison]], and appeared recordings such as ''[[Beautiful Vision]]'' (1982), ''[[Inarticulate Speech of the Heart]]'' (1983), ''[[Live at the Grand Opera House Belfast]]'' (1984), ''[[A Sense of Wonder]]'' (1985), and ''[[No Guru, No Method, No Teacher]]'' (1986).  Lady Bianca also worked with [[John Lee Hooker]] and [[Willie Dixon]].<ref name="AMG"/> In 1984, she met Stanley Lippitt, a songwriter and her eventual husband. She continued to perform locally and undertook more low-key recording work.<ref name="Dennis"/>

After recording [[Demo (music)|demos]] with Lippitt, she was noticed by [[Joe Louis Walker]] who helped arrange a [[recording contract]].<ref name="AMG"/> Her debut solo album, ''Best Kept Secret'' was released in 1995 on Telarc Distribution.<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=best-kept-secret-r224368|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Best Kept Secret''> Overview|accessdate=December 21, 2011|publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref> Her backing work continued in the 1990s, when she worked with [[Frankie Lee (musician)|Frankie Lee]] and [[Maria Muldaur]]. Lady Bianca's next solo effort was the critically acclaimed ''Rollin''' (2001), which was released on the Rooster Blues label.<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=rollin-r533210|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Rollin' ''> Overview|accessdate=December 21, 2011 |publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref> In 2002, she was given the '[[Freedom of the City|Keys to the City]]' in Oakland.<ref name="Dennis"/>

She formed her own record label Magic-O Records, and with Lippitt have their own production and publishing company.<ref name="Lady"/> Further albums were recorded and issued on Magic-O. These included ''All by Myself'' (2004),<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=all-by-myself-r688186|pure_url=yes}}|title=''All by Myself'' > Overview |accessdate=December 21, 2011 |publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref> ''Let Love Have Its Way'' (2005), ''Through a Woman's Eyes'' (2007), and ''A Woman Never Forgets'' (2009).<ref name="Albums"/>

In April 2007, at the Bay Area Black Music Awards, Lady Bianca was awarded as Best Blues Performer. In March 2008, she was voted in to the West Coast Blues Hall of Fame. In 2009, she appeared with Van Morrison at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in [[London]].<ref name="Lady"/> 

Lady Bianca and the Magic-O Rhythm Band have appeared at many blues [[music festival]]s, including the [[San Francisco Blues Festival]] in 1987, and the [[Sarasota Blues Fest]] in 1996.<ref name="Dennis">{{cite web|url=http://souldennis.blogspot.com/2009/01/lady-bianca-thornton.html|title=Lady Bianca Thornton profile at|publisher=Souldennis.blogpsot.com|accessdate=December 21, 2011|date=January 11, 2009}}</ref>

Three of her albums have been nominated for a [[Grammy Award]] – ''Best Kept Secret'', ''Rollin''', and ''Through a Woman's Eyes''. She is currently working on her projected seventh release.<ref name="Lady">{{cite web|url=http://www.ladybianca.com/bios.html|title=Lady Bianca biography at|publisher=Ladybianca.com|accessdate=December 21, 2011}}</ref>
